awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Postoperative Risk Prediction for Heart Failure Patients
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a risk assessment platform embedded with novel machine learning algorithms to predict mortality and adverse events in heart failure patients after cardiac treatments and surgeries. The technology seeks to: 1) address uncertainty and data imbalance issues prevalent in healthcare data, 2) extract important features and biomarkers relevant to post-operative risks, and 3) develop new tools for ultrasound image analysis to predict the probability of adverse events. There is currently no established technology for healthcare professionals in the cardiac care field to analyze multiple data sources for risk assessment pre- and post-cardiac treatment. The proposed technology may help clinicians leverage advanced machine learning tools for treatment outcomes assessment and clinical decision-making. The technology may also promote the use of data science approaches and computer models in other clinical applications. The project seeks to enable accurate risk prediction and enhance confidence in post-operative treatment, improving the quality of cardiac care, and ultimately benefitting cardiac patients.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a software application to predict post-operative risk for end-stage heart failure patients after cardiac surgeries such as heart transplantation or left ventricular assist device (LVAD) implantation. The software application has a back-end server with novel machine learning algorithms trained using electronic health records (EHR) from previous heart transplant and LVAD recipients. Risk prediction is performed using customized machine learning algorithms and statistical risk models. Novel clustering techniques are used to identify groups of patients with similar characteristics, clinical variables of importance, as well as noise and outliers present in the data. The software also offers an easy-to-use interface that provides clients with clinically useful information and a visualization of risk factors linked to the risk prediction for an individual patient.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This I-Corps project develops a Machine Learning (ML) driven risk prediction technology to predict the probability of heart failure patients developing complications after cardiac surgery. The technology is embedded with original ML algorithms to address challenges in clinical data analysis and achieves improved prediction accuracy compared to existing methods. The technology fills the gap that few risk prediction models are available to assess post-operative risk in heart transplant recipients and offers a novel solution to help physicians navigate uncertainty in decision-making. In addition, the project revealed the potential value of the risk prediction tool, including improving patient outcomes and enhancing treatment efficiency. These insights expand the current understanding of how ML-driven risk prediction innovations can meet healthcare needs. Furthermore, the project trains researchers in translating theoretical ML algorithms into solving clinical challenges and builds capacity for future healthcare innovation through the development of entrepreneur skills, market analysis, and user-centered design.

The project bridges the gap between academic research and real-world applications in cardiac care. By advancing the translation of ML-driven risk prediction technologies into practical solutions, the project addresses critical challenges in cardiac care and helps improve patient outcomes. The technology enables healthcare professionals to leverage data science innovations to enhance treatment efficiency, which can potentially extend the survival of heart transplant recipients and improve their quality of life. Clinical utilization of the risk prediction tool may reduce hospital stays, minimize readmissions, and optimize resource allocation, which will promote greater efficiency in healthcare delivery. In addition, the technology promotes the use of data science approaches and computer models in clinical applications, transforming the current practice of clinical risk prediction from basic statistical modeling to ML-based intelligent modeling. In addition to the clinical contributions, the project prepares engineering researchers with the skills and knowledge to navigate technology transfer and commercialization pathways. This ensures that groundbreaking technologies are not only developed but also effectively implemented in the marketplace, which drives innovation in the healthcare industry and delivers substantial societal benefits.

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2024
Modified by: Dongping Du
